Name: Acitron
Description: [Spanish] candied biznaga cactus; made by simmering in a sugar syrup.

Name: Adobado (adavada)
Description: [Spanish] in Texas, a sour marinade paste made with chiles, herbs and vinegar; in New Mexico and El Paso, a marinade for pork made with red New Mexican chiles, Mexican oregano and garlic.

Name: Adobo
Description: [Spanish] piquant sauce or paste used as a seasoning for meats, seafood or poultry. It includes chiles, tomato, vinegar and spices; adobo may also be used for pickling.

Name: Agujas
Description: [Spanish] in northern Mexico, name given to ribs of beef.

Name: Akee, Ackee
Description: Tropical fruit, native to Africa, commonly eaten in Jamaica with salt cod. The cherry-size fruit, slightly oval in shape, has a flavor similar to grapes, and looks like scrambled eggs when cooked. Certain parts of the fruit are toxic when underripe so it is important to identify the stage of maturity before using this fresh fruit, but canned akee is safe. Also known as genipa, genip, ginup, honeyberry, limoncillo, Spanish lime and mamoncillo.

Name: Al Carbon
Description: [Spanish] a dish relating to charcoal grilled or containing meat.

Name: Al Pastor
Description: A term used in Spanish and Italian referring to a dish cooked in the style of shepherd cooking, usually vertically over a grill or spit.

Name: Albondigas
Description: [Spanish] meatballs; made of chicken, shrimp, beef or pork; usually used as a garnish for broth soups or served in tomato sauce as an appetizer or light entree.

Name: Anejo
Description: [Spanish] aged; refers either to certain types of aged liquor or to a cheese which is like a cross between Parmesan and feta.

Name: Anis
Description: [Spanish] Anise; small, elongated seed from the anise plant that tastes like licorice; the anise plant is a member of the carrot family.

Name: Antojito
Description: [Spanish] snack or an appetizer, it means little whim.

Name: Antojitos mexicanos
Description: [Spanish] snacks; corn- or tortilla-based Mexican foods, including enchiladas, tacos and tamales.

Name: Apio
Description: [Spanish] edible root of a tropical plant.

Name: Arroz
Description: [Portuguese] rice. It is not a Spanish term.

Name: Asador
Description: [Spanish] wire mesh stovetop grill which can be used to roast vegetables over an outdoor fire or on the stovetop.

Name: Ates
Description: [Spanish] sweetsop; sweet fruit pastes; an equal amount of fruit pulp and sugar.

Name: Barbacoa
Description: [Spanish] barbecued or pit-cooked meat; often refers to the head of a cow, sheep or goat that has been barbecued or pit-cooked.

Name: Bermuda onion
Description: This big, sweet, ivory-colored onion truly does not come from Bermuda. A sweet, crisp topping for sandwiches, this onion is also a good choice for everyday cooking. Bermudas have a shorter shelf life than the basic yellow onion. Also called Spanish onion.

Name: Birria
Description: Spanish name given to a dish of seasoned meat, then barbecued or steamed.

Name: Borracho
Description: [Spanish] drunken; foods containing liquor, beer or wine.

Name: Bunuelos
Description: [Spanish] bungle; mess up; fritters; sweetened fry bread usually sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar.

Name: Cabrito
Description: [Spanish] unweaned goat; suckling goat; kid goat; usually split and spit roasted whole; considered a delicacy in Mexico and the Southwest; a favorite dish in northern Mexico, especially at Easter.

Name: Cajeta
Description: [Spanish] originally a little wooden box made to hold sweets; burned milk; goat's milk caramel; goat's milk that has been mixed with sugar and cooked into a brown paste; dessert, usually of fruit or milk, cooked with sugar until thick.

Name: Calabacita
Description: [Spanish] squash; zucchini. A variety of summer squash found in Latin American and Mexican cooking.

Name: Calabaza
Description: [Spanish] pumpkin. This pumpkin-like winter squash, usually sold in slices or hunks in markets catering to Central and South Americans. Also known as West Indian pumpkin, calabaza is quite frequently better than pumpkin when cooked in the same way.

Name: Caldillo
Description: [Spanish] little soup; thick stew with beef and chiles; commonly served in El Paso and Juarez.

Name: Calf fries
Description: [Spanish] ranch treat of quick-fried calf scrotum; also called mountain oysters.

Name: Canela
Description: [Spanish] cinnamon; Ceylon cinnamon; lighter in color and more subtle in flavor than cinnamon sold in the United States; dried inner bark of the "Cinnamomum zeylanicum"  tree, which was brought to Mexico from Sri Lanka; canela sticks have a rough, torn appearance, and its soft surface grinds easily in spice mills and blenders.

Name: Capirotada
Description: [Spanish] bread pudding; usually served during Lent and Holy Week (Easter).

Name: Carne Adovada
Description: Pork steak marinated in chile sauce, then roasted or pan fried. Usually served with Spanish rice and refried beans.

Name: Carne adovada
Description: [Spanish] meat cured in red chile sauce; traditional New Mexican dish.

Name: Carne asada
Description: [Spanish] marinated, broiled meat; in Sonora, Mexico means a picnic or cookout where meat is broiled.

Name: Carne seca
Description: [Spanish] dried beef or jerky; was a trail food utilized on the range.

Name: Carne
Description: In Italian and Spanish meaning meat.

Name: Carnitas
Description: [Spanish] little pieces of meat; small chunks of pork which have been seasoned, slow-cooked, and fried crisp in their own fat; it is a traditional taco and enchilada filling.

Name: Cascabel chiles
Description: [Spanish] Little rattler; jingle bells; sleigh bells; small, round, hot chiles that rattle when shaken; measure about 1 1/2 to 2 inches across and have smooth skins; woodsy chile with tones of hazelnut, citrus and tobacco, gives off a wonderful aroma when roasted; great in stews, soups, salsas, salad dressing and vinaigrettes; blend well with apples, pears and other fruits and with spices such as star anise, canela and cinnamon; rbol chiles may be substituted.

Name: Cecina
Description: [Spanish] salted, cured or smoked dried meat strips; similar to carne seca.

Name: Ceviche
Description: [Spanish] raw seafood combined with lime juice; the juice "cooks" the seafood by combining with its protein and turning it opaque.

Name: Chalupa compuesta
Description: [Spanish] adorned little boat; a very popular dish in Arizona.

Name: Chalupas
Description: [Spanish] little boats or little canoes; fried corn tortillas in the shape of a boat or basket containing shredded chicken or beans topped with salsa, guacamole or cheese.

Name: Champurrado
Description: [Spanish] a drink, atole (corn gruel) with chocolate.

Name: Chicos
Description: [Spanish] corn kernels that are roasted, steamed in a horno, then dried; they are not treated with lime; may be cooked for hours to serve as a vegetable, or ground into harinella, which may be used interchangeably with Masa Harina.

Name: Chilaquiles
Description: [Spanish] broken-up old sombreros, a reference to the appearance of the dish; considered a good way to use up stale tortillas; a family-style casserole of tortilla strips, salsa, meat and/or cheese, most often served for breakfast; it is very difficult to find in restaurants. This is a highly seasoned dish, often served as a brunch or lunch dish with eggs or grilled meats.

Name: Chile pasado
Description: [Spanish] chile of the past; roasted, peeled and sun-dried green chiles.

Name: Chiles rellenos
Description: [Spanish] stuffed chiles which are then battered and deep-fried.

Name: Chili con carne
Description: [Spanish] "chili with meat," this dish is a mixture of diced or ground beef and chiles or chili powder (or both). It originated in the Lone Star State and Texans, who commonly refer to it as "a bowl of red." They consider it a crime to add beans to the mixture. In many parts of the country, however, beans are used, and the dish is called "chili con carne with beans."

Name: Chilorio
Description: [Spanish] cooked and shredded meat, fried with a paste of ground chiles and other seasoning.

Name: Chimichanga
Description: [Spanish] stuffed burro fried in deep fat, then topped with cheese, guacamole and chile sauce; found almost exclusively in Arizona.

Name: Chimiquito
Description: [Spanish] stuffed and fried flour tortilla; it is rolled like a flauta or taquito rather than being wrapped like a burrito or chimichanga.

Name: Chongos
Description: [Spanish] a dessert of cooked milk curds.

Name: Chuleta
Description: [Spanish] chop or cutlet, lamb, pork or veal.

Name: Churros
Description: [Spanish] deep-fried cakes named for the shaggy, long-haired Mexican sheep they resemble.

Name: Cilantro
Description: A green herb, similar in appearance to parsley. Also sold dry as seeds, leaves and ground. An essential ingredient to Asian and Mexican dishes. It can be found in Asian as well as Mexican markets and most large supermarkets. Also known as fresh coriander, Mexican parsley and Chinese parsley. It resembles flat-leaf parsley, but the flavor is strong and fresh; the seeds are known as coriander; cilantro is commonly used in salsas and soups; was first introduced to the Mexican Indians by the Spanish.

Name: Cochineal
Description: [Spanish] small red bug crushed to make red food coloring.

Name: Cocido
Description: [Spanish] cooked; boiled; meaty beef and vegetable soup.

Name: Colache
Description: [Spanish] stew made of squash and other vegetables.

Name: Comal
Description: [Spanish] flat iron griddle for cooking tortillas.

Name: Comida
Description: [Spanish] food; main meal of the day.

Name: Comino
Description: [Spanish] cumin; powerful spice used in traditional Southwest cooking; seeds from pods of the indigenous and plentiful Southwestern cumin plant; can be purchased whole or ground; the predominant flavor in dishes such as chili con carne.

Name: Conserva
Description: [Spanish] conserve; preserves made from fruit and usually includes nuts.

Name: Corunda
Description: [Spanish] small cushion-shaped tamal wrapped in a corn husk.

Name: Crema
Description: [Spanish] cream; thickened and soured cream, the equivalent of cr me fr iche; usually a combination of whipping cream and buttermilk; used as a garnish, and it melts easily; sour cream may be substituted, but it is not as rich and is more acidic.

Name: Creme Caramel
Description: Like the Spanish flan, this is a baked custard that is flavored with caramel. When the dish is inverted, the caramel creates a sauce for the dessert.

Name: Cuaresmeno
Description: [Spanish] Lenten; another name for chile jalapeno.

Name: Cumin
Description: Often labeled under its Spanish name, comino; introduced to the Americas by settlers of Portuguese and Spanish origin; from a plant that is a member of the carrot family; seeds are crescent shaped and resemble fuzzy caraway seeds; cumin pairs wonderfully with dried chiles and the slow-cooked flavors of the Southwest; best used toasted and ground as needed; some recipes call for the whole seeds.

Name: Elotes
Description: [Spanish] fresh corn cut from the cob; ear of fresh corn.

Name: Encebollada
Description: [Spanish] a dish, often meat, covered with cooked onions.

Name: Encharito
Description: [Spanish] a huge enchilada made with a flour tortilla; a cross between a burrito and an enchilada.

Name: Enchilada
Description: [Spanish] the word comes from the way the dish is made, by drenching or dipping tortillas en chile; rolled or stacked corn tortillas filled with meat or cheese, covered with chile sauce, then baked.

Name: Enfrijolada
Description: [Spanish] a type of enchilada made with corn tortillas, refried beans and cheese.

Name: Escabeche
Description: [Spanish] pickled; souse; vegetables, especially chiles, marinated or pickled in vinegar. A highly seasoned marinade used to flavor and preserve food. Fish and chicken are the most common foods used for escabeche. First the meat is fried and placed in a dish large enough to hold all of the food in one layer. Then a marinade made of onions, peppers, vinegar, and spices is poured over the food while hot. The whole dish is then allowed to rest overnight and served cold.

Name: Exotic/ethnic sections (food industry term)
Description: Unique products from all over the world. Special sections may feature Asian, Spanish, Italian and other foods or products.

Name: Faison
Description: [Spanish] pheasant; name given to many game birds.

Name: Fajitas
Description: [Spanish] little belts; marinated and grilled skirt steak; called arracheras in Mexico; refers to the cut of meat, not the way it is served; a lower-fat substitute is flank steak.

Name: Fiambre
Description: [Spanish] cooked meat and vegetable salad that is usually marinated.

Name: Flan
Description: This is a term that may be used to describe two different preparations. The first use of this word is describes an open top tart that is filled with pastry cream and topped with fruit. Flan is used in Spanish and Mexican cooking to describe an egg custard that is baked in a large shallow dish, and flavored with caramel. The dish is inverted when served and the excess caramel is used as a sauce for the flan. The flan may be flavored with orange, anise, cinnamon, or liqueur. [Spanish] traditional Mexican and Southwestern baked caramel custard dessert; similar to the French "creme caramel" or "creme brulee."

Name: Flautas
Description: [Spanish] flutes; filled, tightly rolled, and deep-fried enchiladas.

Name: Frijoles refritos
Description: [Spanish] refried beans; a paste of stewed pinto beans fried in fat with onions and garlic and frequently includes chiles.

Name: Frijoles
Description: [Spanish] beans; usually refers to stewed pinto beans; varieties are Anasazi, black turtle, bollito, pinto or red (Mexican strawberry).

Name: Fritada
Description: [Spanish] stew usually made with goat meat, which always contains some animal blood.

Name: Garnacha
Description: [Spanish] round antojito of tortilla dough; tartlets of fried masa filled with black bean paste and ground beef, covered with tomato sauce, and sprinkled with cheese; usually served as an appetizer.

Name: Gaspacho, Gazpacho
Description: Cold Spanish vegetable soup made with meat broth, crushed fresh tomatoes, and diced raw vegetables like onions, cucumbers, and peppers.

Name: Gazpacho
Description: A cold spicy vegetable soup served throughout all of the Spanish countries. The most common version is one made with a coarse puree of fresh tomatoes flavored with vinegar and olive oil, embellished with diced raw vegetables like onions, cucumbers, and peppers. A light gazpacho is made with a puree of cucumber, and served with an array of garnishes for the diner to choose from. Roasted almonds, avocados, and croutons are common garnishes.

Name: Gorditas
Description: [Spanish] little fat ones; corn flour patties, usually slit, then stuffed; often found unslit, with the filling served on top or between two of them.

Name: Guacamole
Description: [Spanish] a dip made of mashed avocadoes seasoned with onions, tomatoes, garlic, chiles, and cilantro. This is mostly eaten as a dip for fried corn chips, but it is also very good with raw vegetables and as a topping for various dishes.. You may also use it as a filling for burritos and tacos.

Name: Guayaba
Description: [Spanish] guava; a yellow-green fruit with pale, faintly pink flesh, about the size of a plum; extremely fragrant when ripe; Guava paste is often served with cream cheese as dessert; the fruit is cooked with sugar until thick, then canned or shaped into blocks.

Name: Harina de maiz
Description: [Spanish] flour made from dried corn; cornmeal; Masa Harina is the brand name of the product made by Quaker.

Name: Harina enraizado
Description: [Spanish] flour made from sprouted wheat; also called panocha.

Name: Harina
Description: [Spanish] flour; usually refers to wheat flour.

Name: Harinilla; harinela
Description: [Spanish] meal made of finely ground chicos; can be used interchangeably with masa harina.

Name: Herba santa
Description: [Spanish] holy herb; often labeled as hoja santa, it contains licorice and sassafras flavors; has a broad, flat leaf; equal parts fresh basil and tarragon may be substituted using about half as much by volume as hierba santa.

Name: Hibiscus blossoms
Description: Also called sorrel blossoms, these make a delicious iced tea. Find in Latin and Caribbean markets. Jamaica is the Spanish name; the blossoms of this tropical plant provide a brilliant color and an intense blackberry and dried cherry flavor to cocktails, marinades and vinaigrettes; Jamaica is also a beverage made from this blossom.

Name: Hoja santa
Description: [Spanish] large leaf used in cooking in southern Mexico.

Name: Horchata
Description: [Spanish] beverage made with rice or melon.

Name: Huauzoncle (guauzontle)
Description: [Spanish] wild green with thin serrated leaves.

Name: Huevos rancheros
Description: [Spanish] ranch-style eggs. A Mexican dish of fried eggs served atop a tortilla and covered with a tomato sauce.

Name: Huitlacoche
Description: [Spanish] corn fungus delicacy; sleepy excrement (Aztec); common in central Mexico; during the rainy season, a fungus develops between the husks and the ripe kernels where the kernels will blacken, contort and swell to form this musty fungus; valued for centuries in Mexico; has an earthy and distinct taste finally similar to mushrooms or truffles; lends a black hue and resonant aroma to stuffings for empanadas, tamales and quesadillas; makes distinctive sauces; usually sold cut from the cob and frozen; needs cooking to release flavor and aroma; often sauteed with roasted garlic and onions, and either fresh marjoram, oregano or epazote, then simmered with a little water or stock; harvested during the rainy season, usually late spring to early fall.

Name: Jamaica
Description: [Spanish] hibiscus; deep red calyxes that cover the blossoms before the flowers open; used to flavor beverages; commonly labeled sorrel in markets.

Name: Jitomate
Description: [Spanish] word for the tomato most commonly used in Mexico's interior.

Name: Limon
Description: [Spanish] Lemon; in Mexico it usually refers to the small tart Mexican lime.

Name: Machaca
Description: [Spanish] from the verb machacar, which means to pound or break something into small pieces; meat that has been stewed, roasted or broiled, then shredded; it is typical of Sonoran cooking.

Name: Machacado
Description: [Spanish] mashed; name of a dish of scrambled eggs and shredded dried meat.

Name: Maizena
Description: [Spanish] cornstarch; a product of Mexico which comes in almond, chocolate, cinnamon, coconut, guava, mango, pineapple and vanilla flavors; commonly used to make Atole.

Name: Manchamantel
Description: [Spanish] "tablecloth stainer." Usually refers to sauces that do not wash out easily.

Name: Manchego
Description: [Spanish] an aged sheep's milk cheese that is dry and crumbly; packed in straw and weighted; usually grated for use in quesadillas and empanadas; substitute good Parmesan or aged white Cheddar.

Name: Mangos
Description: [Spanish] mangoes; one of the most popular fruits in the Southwest and Mexico; it has a peach-like taste and flowery aroma; the skin is pink, red, gold and green; the flesh is deep yellow and juicy; to slice the fruit, free it from the flat, oval pit in large pieces. There are some two hundred varieties. They are usually eaten ripe, as a fruit or in salsa. Green mangoes make great salads and chutneys.

Name: Mano
Description: [Spanish] hand; implement used to grind corn and chiles on a metate.

Name: Manteca
Description: [Spanish] lard; fat; probably the most frequently used ingredient in traditional Mexican cooking; has approximately half the cholesterol of butter; fresh rendered lard is best; it is usually best to substitute vegetable shortening unless fresh lard is available.

Name: Manzanilla Olive
Description: Spanish green olive, lightly lye-cured then packed in salt and lactic acid; available unpitted and/or stuffed.

Name: Masa
Description: [Spanish] dough; dough of ground dried corn and flour; usually refers to ground nixtamal; instant corn flour tortilla mix; cornmeal dough made from dried corn kernels that have been softened in a lime solution, then ground; fresh frozen masa is available in supermarkets throughout the Southwest; comes finely ground in a dehydrated form and can be used to make tortillas and tamales.

Name: Menudo
Description: [Spanish] tripe and cow's foot soup or stew; fiery Mexican "hangover cure," traditionally eaten on Saturday and Sunday; traditional dish for New Year's Day; normally served with lime wedges, oregano, red pepper flakes and hot tortillas.

Name: Merienda
Description: [Spanish] afternoon tea following the daily siesta.

Name: Mescal
Description: [Spanish] liquor distilled from fermented juice of the maguey cactus.

Name: Migas
Description: [Spanish] leftovers; crumbs; a dish made of eggs scrambled with chorizo, tortilla chips, onions, tomatoes, cheese and chiles, it is normally eaten for breakfast; also called huevos con tostaditos.

Name: Molcajete
Description: [Spanish] mortar made from volcanic stone used for grinding chiles.

Name: Mole negro
Description: [Spanish] the best known of Oaxaca's famous "seven moles."

Name: Mole
Description: [Spanish] taken from the Nahuatl word "Molli," meaning concoction; an assortment of thick sauces used in Mexican cooking made of chiles. These sauces are made with one or many chiles, and flavored with cumin, coriander, cinnamon, nuts, seeds, and chocolate. one of the most common ingredients of mole sauce is chocolate; one of the oldest known sauces. Their flavor is rich, smoky, and very complex. Some recipes are made with fresh herbs and have a green color. Chicken, turkey, and pork are then simmered in this sauce.

Name: Molinillo
Description: [Spanish] a wooden whisk used to whip hot chocolate; the handle is rolled between the palms of the hands, whipping the mixture until it is frothy.

Name: Molletes
Description: [Spanish] yeast rolls flavored with anise; toasted open-faced sandwich filled with refried beans and cheese.

Name: Morcilla
Description: [Spanish] pork mixed with pig's blood and spices and steamed within the animal's stomach.

Name: Mostarda di Cremona
Description: [Spanish] These are fruits cooked and marinated in a spicy, mustard flavored syrup. It is a classic accompaniment to bollito misto. These fruits are also used in sauces for veal, and assorted stuffed pasta fillings.

Name: Nachos
Description: [Spanish] tortilla chips that are topped with cheese, chiles, etc., then heated until the cheese melts; originated in El Paso, Texas.

Name: Natilla
Description: [Spanish] custard dessert; similar to floating island, with stiffly beaten egg whites layered on top of an egg custard; often accompanied with fresh or poached fruits.

Name: Nixtamal
Description: [Spanish] hominy; lime-slaked corn; used to make posole or ground into masa, or dough, to make tortillas.

Name: Noodles - Japanese
Description: [Spanish] paddles (leaves) of the prickly pear (nopal) cactus; they are firm and crunchy; the smaller the paddle, the more tender; nopales have a flavor similar to green beans and can be eaten raw or cooked; sliced green beans can be substituted.

Name: Udon Noodles
Description: [Spanish] cactus paddles cut into strips or dices; usually refers to the canned and pickled cactus.

Name: Ocote
Description: [Spanish] small strips of pine used to kindle a fire.

Name: Oloroso
Description: [Spanish] a type of sherry. Oloroso means fragrant in Spanish and this sherry has an intense bouquet.

Name: Pachola
Description: [Spanish] thin, half circle-shaped piece of ground meat.

Name: Paella
Description: A Spanish rice dish originating in the town of Valencia. There are hundreds of recipes for paella, all claiming to be authentic. The only ingredients that are necessary for paella are rice, tomatoes, and saffron. Other ingredients are chicken, chorizo, mussels, squid, peppers, and beans. More elaborate preparations include shrimp, lobster, and duck.

Name: Panela
Description: [Spanish] white cheese made with rennet; slightly salty; it holds its shape when melted; normally sold in blocks or rounds; often sliced thick and broiled or baked; Monterey Jack can be substituted.

Name: Passion fruit
Description: Purplish-brown on the outside, filled with (edible) pits and orange flesh inside. Unadulterated, it is tart and hard to take. Passionfruit get its name from its flowers, which Spanish missionaries thought resembled symbols of Christ's Passion, such as the crown of thorns.

Name: Campanelle
Description: [Spanish] envelopes of dough made of plantains filled with tasty ingredients.

Name: Pescado
Description: A Spanish dish made up of ground pork and beef, tomatoes, garlic, onions, and other foods, depending on the region. In Mexico, picadillo is used as a stuffing.

Name: Pesce
Description: [Spanish] hash; shredded or ground beef, spices and other ingredients; normally used as a filling.

Name: Pickapeppa Sauce
Description: [Spanish] an unrefined cane sugar that is purchased in molded hard cones; It is beige to brown in color; the deeper the color, the more molasses flavor it has; dark brown sugar may be substituted.

Name: Picoso
Description: [Spanish] pineapples; used in salsas, relishes, desserts and cocktails.

Name: Pike
Description: [Spanish] pine nuts, pignolis; seeds of the pi on pine which ripen in the crevices of pine cones throughout the desert Southwest; delicious raw or toasted; store tightly covered and either refrigerate or freeze them, depending on how soon they are to be used.

Name: Pimenton
Description: [Spanish] sauce containing ground nuts or seeds and spices; Indian stew or fricassee thickened by its ingredients rather than by flour.

Name: Piquant
Description: [Spanish] plantain; a tropical plant resembling the banana; very large with a thick skin; the fruit is deeper yellow than that of the banana; cooked, unripe platana is eaten like a potato; when ripe, the skins are black, and this is when they are sweetest; platanas will ripen after being harvested.

Name: Piquante Sauce
Description: [Spanish] banana; coarse-textured banana that cannot be eaten raw.

Name: Progressive grocer associates, llc (food industry term)
Promotion money (food industry term)
Description: [Spanish] a stand in the market or on the street.

Name: Quelitas
Description: [Spanish] lamb's quarters; pigweed; goosefoot; wild spinach; wild greens; bean and spinach dish seasoned with bacon and chile.

Name: Quesadilla
Description: [Spanish] sandwich; flour tortilla turnover which is usually stuffed with cheese, then toasted, fried or baked. Originally a corn masa empanada filled with meat then deep fried. Modern versions found throughout restaurants in the US are made with flour tortillas that are filled with cheese and perhaps beans, meat, salsa. or vegetables, and folded over when cooked. Usually pan-fried or cooked under a broiler.

Name: Queso anejo
Description: [Spanish] aged cheese; salty white cheese slightly similar to feta in flavor, but since it is not brined, its flavor is somewhat milder; a good substitute is grated feta cheese.

Name: Queso asadero
Description: [Spanish] also known as quesilla de Oaxaca; a rubbery-textured cheese that is pulled and twisted into strands; traditionally used in fillings where it becomes stringy when heated; whole-milk mozzarella, Monterey jack or Muenster may be substituted.

Name: Queso blanco
Description: [Spanish] fresh white cheese, often called queso fresco.

Name: Queso flameado
Description: [Spanish] flamed cheese; queso fundido (melted cheese); cheese roasted over a flame.

Name: Queso fresco
Description: [Spanish] cheese which has a texture similar to farmer's cheese; crumbly white cheese made from partially skimmed milk; lightly tangy and very subtle; usually sold in small round cakes; used for fillings and crumbled into soups and over sauces; often called queso blanco; white Cheddar or a mixture of farmer's and feta cheese are fairly good substitutes.

Name: Quince
Description: This yellow-skinned fruit looks and tastes like a cross between an apple and a pear. Its texture and flavor make it better cooked than raw. Its high pectin content makes it ideal for use in jams, jellies and preserves. Introduced to Latin America by the Spanish and/or Portuguese; looks like a large pear, but is hard and very sour; usually cooked with sugar, after which it becomes faint pink.

Name: Rajas
Description: [Spanish] strips; usually refers to strips or ribbons of roasted or sauteed green chiles and onion.

Name: Refrito
Description: [Spanish] refried; usually describes beans that are cooked, mashed, and fried in lard.

Name: Renuevos de rastrojo
Description: [Spanish] tumbleweed shoots; they have a wild bean flavor and can be used as a vegetable or in salads.

Name: Resquesin
Description: [Spanish] curd cheese; often called queso fresco or queso blanco.

Name: Rice, Valencia
Description: Valencia rice (sometimes sold as paella rice), is a large white oval grain. Grown in Spain, it is similar to Arborio. It's the rice used for paella, the Spanish dish that pairs rice with seafood, chicken, rabbit or chorizo and vegetables.

Name: Ristra
Description: [Spanish] string of red chiles for drying in the sun.

Name: Salpicon
Description: [Spanish] shredded or finely cut; Mexican shredded meat salad; hash. Cooked food cut into tiny pieces, usually as a filling for pastry.

Name: Salsa
Description: [Spanish and Italian] sauce. Salsa refers to cooked or fresh combinations of fruits and/or vegetables. The most popular is the Latino mixture of tomatoes, onion and chile peppers.

Name: Sangria
Description: [Spanish] drink made from sweet red wine, pieces of fresh fruit (usually orange and lemon), spices (cinnamon, cloves).:

Name: Sofrito
Description: [Spanish] famous seasoning mix which includes cured ham, lard or canola oil, oregano, onion, green pepper, sweet chile peppers, fresh coriander leaves and garlic.

Name: Sopa seca
Description: [Spanish] dry soup with very little liquid left after cooking.

Name: Sopaipillas
Description: [Spanish] sofa pillows; fritters soaked in honey; a puffed, fried bread, served with honey (or a mixture of honey and melted butter) or syrup or slit, then filled with various stuffings.

Name: Sopes
Description: [Spanish] little round antojitos of tortilla dough.

Name: Tamal (tamale)
Description: [Spanish] any filling enclosed in masa, wrapped in a corn husk or parchment paper, and steamed; the plural is tamales. The cornmeal is spread on a corn husk, then filled with chile-seasoned mixture of meats and red pepper, rolled, tied and steamed.

Name: Tamarindo
Description: [Spanish] sometimes labeled as Indian dates; a The pod is bout four inches long; they have a brown papery outer skin that covers the sticky pulp, fibers and seeds; it makes a wonderful hot weather drink; also great for sauces and chiles when combined with dried chiles; a primary ingredient in both Worcestershire and Pick-a-Peppa sauces; also sold in dried bricks with its seeds, as frozen pulp and puree, and as canned paste; fresh pods can be purchased from later summer through early spring.

Name: Tejano
Description: [Spanish] Texan; often refers to the early Mexican settlers in Texas.

Name: Tejolote
Description: [Spanish] pestle used to grind items in a molcajete.

Name: Tembleque
Description: [Spanish] a coconut dessert; a good commercial product is the Goya brand.

Name: Tepin
Description: [Spanish] a dried chile; chile tepin; wild form of the pequ n, it grows along the Mexican and U.S. border; round, measuring about 1/2 inch across; have a searing, dry heat; used in sauces, salsas and stews; Substitute pequ ns if these are not available.

Name: Tequila
Description: [Spanish] a pale, sharp-tasting liquor distilled from the agave plant (maguey cactus); the stem of the agave, known also as the century plant, is used in making tequila; it is produced near Tequila in the state of Jalisco, Mexico.

Name: Tocino
Description: [Spanish] bacon. Cured ham with added color.

Name: Tomatillos (tomates verdes)
Description: [Spanish] frescadillas; plum-sized, bright green fruit, covered with a light green papery husk; they have a citrus-like, acidic flavor; taste best when they are brilliant green in color; often called green tomatoes, they are more closely related to the kiwi fruit than to tomatoes, and are members of the gooseberry family. Also a member of the nightshade family; originally eaten by the Aztecs; the best substitute is small green tomatoes. If using fresh, remove the papery husks. Canned are a good substitute, but rinse well before using.

Name: Torta
Description: [Spanish] hero sandwich; often made with a bolillo; also made with tortillas fried semi-crisp.

Name: Tortilladora
Description: [Spanish] small handcranked machine for making tortillas.

Name: Tortilleria
Description: [Spanish] establishment where tortillas are made and sold.

Name: Tostada
Description: [Spanish] corn tortilla fried crisp and garnished.

Name: Tostados
Description: [Spanish] fried corn tortillas with toppings; bowls made by frying corn and flour tortillas in a tostado fryer.

Name: Totopos, tostaditas
Description: [Spanish] southern Mexican term for tortilla chips.

Name: Tunas
Description: [Spanish] prickly pear cactus fruits which turn from green to ruby red; their juice is magenta-colored; their exotic flavor is like a blend of pomegranates, cherries and strawberries; the fruit is used in making jelly, candies and syrup.

Name: Vainilla
Description: [Spanish] vanilla; it was cultivated by the Aztecs and is native to the New World; the intensely fragrant bean from a variety of orchid native to Mexico; used to flavor desserts, ice cream and beverages; do not purchase the inexpensive imitations which are made from the tonka bean because it may be a carcinogen.

Name: Vampiro
Description: [Spanish] drink made with Sangrita and tequila.

Name: Venado
Description: [Spanish] venison; antelope or deer meat; a lean meat, it needs moist heat to keep it tender.

Name: Washed-rind
Description: Frequently orange, rinds washed or rubbed with brine, wine, beer or brandy (pont l'eveque, tallegio, Spanish mahon).

Name: Yerba buena
Description: [Spanish] good herb; wild mint; cilantro is an acceptable substitute.

Name: Yucca
Description: [Spanish] cassava; manioc; dark-skinned fleshy starchy root of a tropical plant used in many Hispanic dishes; soft white flesh; cooked and mashed for side dishes, sweetened and fried for desserts or cooked into soups and stews to serve as a thickener; can also be thinly sliced and fried into chips; it is the root from which tapioca is made.
